story: The Question Time audience member, known as Julie Dawes, warned the panel it would be a &ldquocatastrophic time to change the Prime Minister.Speaking on the show, Conservative MP Andrea Jenkyns said she supports replacing Theresa May with either Boris Johnson or David Davis, claiming that only those who &ldquobelieve in Brexit can deliver it effectively.But, the audience members question sparked a huge row between the panel over Britain&rsquos Brexit strategy.The host returned to Ms Dawes, who said: &ldquoI despair really, I just despair with the lot of you, to be honest.                &lsquoWe could TAKE Falklands back after Brexit&rsquo- Argentinian government                 &rsquoPeople stopped talking to me over Brexit&rsquo says key Leave organiser&ldquoThey all forget what they are there for. Right across all parties.&ldquoThe decision has been made. People keep asking for further referenda.&ldquoThe decision was made and we are going to keep having referenda until politicians get the decision they want.During the BBC show, Tory MP and Brexit supporter Ms Jenkyns said Mr Johnson or Mr Davis should have led Britain&rsquos negotiations with Brussels.She said: &ldquoAs I&rsquove said many times I think the only people who can actually deliver Brexit are people who believe in Brexit.&ldquoNot one party leader has taken these opportunities for Britain to take it forward including my Prime Minister Theresa May.&ldquoIt must be a Brexiteer, so that&rsquos either David Davis or Boris Johnson because they have stood up for what they believe in.She added: &ldquoI&rsquom a naturally loyal person but I am actually loyal to my constituents.&ldquoThere are&nbsptoo many politicians who sit on the fence for an easy life, but sometimes you&rsquove got to put your head above the parapet and stand up for what you believe in.Brexit news: Question Time audience member ripped into the panel over Brexit (Image: BBC)&ldquoI&rsquom standing up for the 17.3 million people who voted for Leave and I think this Government should deliver it.Speaking later, Ms Jenkyns claimed the UK has not used its &ldquostrong hand of being such an important trading partner with the EU in negotiations.Theresa May left the Brussels summit last week optimistic, despite EU leaders&nbspdeciding&nbspto push back a November meeting until &ldquodecisive progress has been made in negotiations.Speaking in the House of Commons on Thursday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab warned the EU about a no deal, should they refuse to budge in negotiations.He said: &ldquoThere certainly is a risk of no deal especially if the EU engage in a deliberately intransigent approach.

story: Labour MP Lisa Nandy clashed with the BBC Question Time audience member over Brexit.The audience member claimed all parties should have worked together to deliver Britain&rsquos departure from the European Union.Ms Nandy claimed the Labour Party have offered to work with the Government since &ldquoday one sparking a fierce clash.The BBC audience member said: &ldquoI really despair the issue for me is, you guys should all be working together on this.                Brexiteer MP reveals what 'team captain' May said to WIN his support&ldquoThis is the biggest cross-political issue in my lifetime.Ms Nandy replied: &ldquoHow can you do that when the Tory party can&rsquot even work with itself?Groans were heard from some members of the BBC crowed as the audience member tried to reply.The Labour Party MP added: &ldquoThat is the offer that has been on the table since day one.&ldquoBut, the real negotiation is still happening around the cabinet table.The Question Time audience member pointed out isions in the Labour Party over Brexit.He said: &ldquoWith respect, the Labour Party can&rsquot argue amongst themselves at the moment, can they?The Labour MP said: &ldquoWe have had a really clear position for a long time. We have been pushing Theresa May for a UK wide customs union and access to the single market in order to protect jobs.&ldquoWe have said since day one, &lsquowork with us to negotiate this in the national interest.The&nbspangry Question Time audience member simply replied: &ldquoYou are just illustrating my point.Ms Nandy refused to accept the audience members argument. She said: &ldquoI&rsquom sorry I totally disagree with this. If you say that all politicians are not trying to sort this out, then you lead us down a path to despair and no deal. We cannot afford that.Brexit news: Question Time audience member clashed with Labour MP Lisa Nandy (Image: BBC)The Prime Minister has been unable to secure a Brexit deal with the European Union and at the EU summit last week EU leaders decided to push back a November meeting until &ldquodecisive progress has been made in negotiations.The major sticking point in negotiations remains the Irish border, with the EU&rsquos proposed backstop being outright rejected by the Prime Minister, as it would effectively create a border down the middle of the Irish Sea.Speaking in the House of Commons on Thursday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab warned the EU about a no deal, should they refuse to budge in negotiations.He said: &ldquoThere certainly is a risk of no deal especially if the EU engage in a deliberately intransigent approach.

They call it a &lsquopeople's vote&rsquo, but we had a people's vote and the people chose to leave.The Labour Party shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer has claimed the party would prefer a general election over a second referendum but warned all options&nbspremain&nbsp&ldquoon the table should Mrs May&rsquos deal get voted down in the House of Commons.

title: clocks change 2018 why do clocks go back when is winter
story: CLOCKS CHANGE: On Sunday the clocks will go backwards an hour  (Image: )On Sunday, October 28 at 2am, the clocks will go backwards by one hour as the UK leaves British Summer Time (BST) behind.&nbspThis will give everyone an extra hour in bed but will also bring darker evenings.&nbspAfter a glorious summer, many Brits will have forgotten just how cold it can get during winter.But with temperatures expected to plunge by 20C this weekend, the UK will have a rather chilly start to our return to GMT.                When do clocks go back - how can this INCREASE dangerous car crashes?                Clocks go back: Will my iPhone update automatically? Will my android?Why do the clocks go back?&nbspIn 1916, Parliament passed The Summer Time Act following a campaign by builder William Willet.&nbspThe Summer Time Act introduced a day in March on which the clocks would go forward for the UK to enter into BST and a day in October for the clocks to go back so the time reverts to Greenwich Mean Time.These days are the last Sunday of March and the last Sunday of October.&nbspThe clocks go forwards in March to give an extra hour of daylight during the summer.Coinciding with the clock change, Sunday, October 28 is National Sleep In Day.How to prepare for winterThe Sleep Council&rsquos Lisa Artis is urging people to utilise the extra hour gained from the clocks changing to reset their bedtime routine.&nbspMs Artis told Express: &ldquoThe extra hour in bed when clocks go back for British winter time is the perfect opportunity to readjust your routine if you&rsquove been having trouble sleeping.&ldquoA good night&rsquos sleep is vital for our general health and wellbeing, so National Sleep In Day is a great opportunity to reassess our sleeping habits and look at what could be causing any sleep problems.                Clocks go back 2018: What day do the clocks go back?                 How to get to sleep when the clocks go back this weekend: Six tipsAs well as a good nights sleep, Dr Sarita Robinson, principal lecturer in psychology at the University of Central Lancashire said one way to embrace the darker mornings and nights is to get organised.Dr Robinson said: &ldquoGetting organised now for the impact of colder weather can take a significant amount of strain out of the autumn and winter period.&nbsp&ldquoBuying de-icer for the car, grit for the driveway or even getting a few Christmas presents now can help reduce stress and mean that you&rsquore not faced with the last minute rush for the festive season.&nbsp&ldquoPeople can also feel stressed out by work or family life when they try to do too many things at the same time.&nbspGetting organised is one way to be ready for winter (Image: )&ldquoDuring the winter season, it's important to try and get things back into balance.&nbsp&ldquoThere are a few simple changes that can be made to help do this, including monotasking, which involves focusing on one activity at a time, such as going to a museum and enjoying your visit at a slow pace.&ldquoAs the days get shorter, we often feel like crawling under the duvet, but getting some exercise and daylight can help us to maintain a healthy sleep pattern.&nbsp&ldquoGoing for a walk in a local park for a couple of hours is one way to help kids get out and about, and tire out the ones who are poor sleepers.CLOCKS CHANGE: Keeping active and heading out for a walk can get rid of winter tiredness (Image: )Another tip is to invest in a clock with a light feature, which on dark mornings will wake you up with light rather than a blaring alarm.&nbspHealthy eating and exercise could also stave off illnesses associated with the winter months.The NHS advises regular consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products will help to boost your immune system.To keep winter tiredness at bay, the NHS also suggests getting outdoors in natural daylight as much as possible.

title: Asda news job losses supermarket news sainsburys
story: Sources have revealed the job losses will happen next year. The roles are under consultation but up to 2,500 jobs are under threat.It follows the supermarket's proposed &pound12billion merger with Sainsbury's which shocked the industry earlier this year.Bosses at the firms said at the time no stores would be closed. However, they have since admitted authorities investigating the deal could force some to shut.The news follows Debenhams yesterday revealing store closures.                Pregnant mother&rsquos FURY as Asda driver REFUSES to lug shopping upstairsAreas of work affected by any changes at Asda include petrol, bakery, back office and so-called hosting.Jobs in the George areas of Asda stores could also be affected, it is understood.The company declined to comment on any potential job cuts but sources told Express the job losses were not related to the merger with Sainsbury's.A statement from the firm said: In a competitive retail market, where customers rightly expect great value and ease of service, we must always look at how we can work more quickly and efficiently for them - and, inevitably, that means we need to consider changing the roles we need our colleagues to do or the hours needed in particular parts of our stores.Asda latest: Up to 2,500 jobs may go at the supermarket giant (Image: EXPRESS)We believe the proposed changes we are consulting on would allow us to do a better job for our customers.We also recognise that discussions about potential change aren't easy. If the decision is taken to implement the proposed changes, we would work with our colleagues to look at the potential impact of these proposals on them.It is understood that consultations with iniduals will not start until the new year and any redundancies will take place in February at the earliest.Gary Carter, national officer of the GMB union, said: These proposed redundancies are a hammer blow to Asda workers. The timing of this announcement, in the run-up to Christmas, is doubly appalling.&nbspAsda is performing well and is highly profitable because of the hard work of our members, who are the backbone of the company. GMB will fight tooth and nail for every single job.These cuts make no sense whatsoever. Slashing our members' jobs would hurt the service Asda customers receive.With all the speculation surrounding the proposed Sainsbury's merger and potential sell-off of stores, this news will not put anyone's mind at rest.

title: 102 year old man slept on roof three nights
story: Ordeal...the flat-roofed extension where Mr Easton fell (Image: BBCAPEX)Ron Easton was found on the flat roof of his home in Bigbury-on-Sea, Devon, when a neighbour noticed his milk delivery had not been collected.Known locally as Ton-Up Ron, the former racing driver was airlifted to hospital. He is in a stable condition.When Trish Bagley arrived at Mr Easton's home on Wednesday morning there was no answer at his door and he was not answering his phone.Ms Bagley, who delivers milk and papers to Mr Easton, raised the alarm after finding two unopened bottles.                WATCH: 102-year-old man takes on the ice bucket challenge                Squatters move into home of 101-year-old woman while she is in...She said: I thought he was asleep but I really needed someone to have a look.She alerted a shopkeeper who then called out a maintenance man to investigate.After he was found on the roof of his house, Mr Easton was brought down by Devon and Somerset Fire and Rescue Service on a stretcher and flown to hospital by Devon Air Ambulance.Derriford Hospital in Plymouth confirmed yesterday that he remains in hospital in a stable condition.Ron Easton was airlifted to hospital (Image: APEX)Ms Bagley said: I had no idea he was there, I just knew something was wrong. He always takes his milk in every day so alarm bells rang - Monday and Tuesday's milk was there so he was probably there from Sunday.It is understood that Mr Easton may have been adjusting his TV aerial when he fell.Ms Bagley said: The ladder was on the wrong side of the house so no one could see it.He must have slipped or something, we just don't know.He's a strong man. He's always out in the garden. Hopefully he will make a full recovery.&lsquoHe&rsquos a strong man...&rsquo Ron Easton, 102 (Image: APEX)Mr Easton was found lying facedown with a bucket of tools next to him. The fire service confirmed that a man had fallen on the flat roof extension to his home.It added: It appears he had climbed on to the roof using a ladder.Crews attended and rescued the man using ladders and the stretcher from the air ambulance.Neighbour Trish Bagley raised alarm (Image: BBCAPEX)The first paramedic on the scene was Nigel Toms from South Western Ambulance Service. He said: The man was lying between his house and garage, so he was in a bit of a pickle.I reached him fairly easily and got a response. Then we worked together to extricate him from the roof.He added: It was a good team effort. His life was definitely at risk so he's a very fortunate man.

story: If people knew about the possibility of a second referendum during the 2016 vote on Brexit then the Leave campaign would have won a &ldquoheavy victory, believes Lord Finkelstein.Speaking today in the House of Lords, he said: &ldquoIf during the European referendum we had said there was going to be a second chance to vote it would have changed the result profoundly.&ldquoLeave would have won a heavy victory, and would&rsquove established a national consensus behind Brexit.&ldquoAny second vote would have started in a fundamentally different place, but during all the debates in Parliament, no-one suggested two votes, no-one proposed a second referendum. It will also very likely produce an outcome that reminds disputed.&ldquoLet us be clear that this so-called &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo&nbspif it ever took place, would indeed be a second referendum.&ldquoThe idea at Labour conference that this might be a referendum without a Remain option was obviously ridiculous.&ldquoMr Corbyn appeared to be suggesting we might be offered two options in such a referendum, both of which he was against.Brexit news: Lord Finkelstein pointed out that no-one suggested two votes in 2016 (Image: GettyParliament TV)The Lord&rsquos comments come after Blair, Heseltine and Clegg chose a host of European newspapers to demand a second Brexit referendum.They took a double swipe at Brexit supporters by saying they were either &ldquonaive optimists or &ldquocynical pessimists.Mr Clegg joined calls for a second referendum at the end of the negotiations which he claimed would be the &ldquofirst vote on the real facts of Brexit.The self-styled &lsquoPeople&rsquos Vote&rsquo campaign, which is backed by some Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative MPs, is campaigning for a second referendum on whatever deal Theresa May negotiates.The three anti-Brexit campaigners claimed in a joint article that Brexiteers continue to live in a fantasy land of denial.They added: &ldquoRegardless of what path the UK takes in the coming weeks, there can be no denying that a strong European Union will remain in the UK&rsquos interests.Its ability to bring such a erse group of states together and bind them under law and in support of human rights, free markets and free trade is a magnificent achievement and one that should never be sold short or under-valued.As leaders from different political traditions in Britain we have disagreed about much in the past, but what we have in common- our support for democracy, the rule of law, free expression and free trade - are also fundamental European values and they are all worth defending.

They agree with me that no deal would be bad for London, our country, and the EU.They&rsquod be criticised, indeed our Government would be&nbspcriticised,&nbspif we went through with that scenario.According to generous estimations, 700,000 protesters marched on Downing Street in a bid to force a vote on the Government&rsquos Brexit deal.Mr Khan believes the People's Vote movement has legs as people turn their back on the democratic EU referendum held in 2016.The Remainer said Londoners are waking up to the &ldquolies, mistruths and deceptions that have been exposed over the last two years, adding: &ldquoMore people are changing their minds.

title: EU news Italy budget European Union Eurozone currency finance latest
story: Careful reforms to the EU&rsquos single currency bloc remain a work in progress, which prompted influential MEP Guy Verhofstadt to demand more urgency from Brussels to conclude its work before the next crisis strikes.The EU&rsquos top officials fear that next financial meltdown could be born out of Italy&rsquos plan to run at a 2.4 percent of GDP, which has been returned to Rome with a demand for change by the European Commission.On Tuesday, the powerful Brussels executive rejected a national budget for the first time since introducing new post-crisis fiscal rules in 2014, which were designed to avoid another disaster like Greece.They told Italy&rsquos populist government comprised of the Five Star Movement and League to redraft their budget and send it back to Brussels within three weeks or face an &ldquoexcessive deficit procedure, which could lead to sanctions of up to &euro9billion.                Matteo Salvini accuses France of forcing child migrants back to Italy                EU CRISIS: Eurozone growth slips to SLOWEST rate in TWO YEARSOf course, Rome&rsquos populist government, who propelled themselves to power on the promise of ripping up austerity policies and to pump cash into the economy, were quick to hit back at Brussels and refuse to budge.And their arguments are justified, after all the EU&rsquos own guidelines permits a country&rsquos deficit to be below three percent.Brussels&rsquo concerns surround Italy&rsquos growing pile of public debt, which stands at 131 percent of GDP, and is second only to Greece&rsquos in the bloc.Vladis Dombrovskis, the European Commission vice-president responsible for the euro, said it had &ldquono alternative but to reject Italy&rsquos planned fiscal stimulus.EU news: Officials warn Eurozone at risk if Commission avoids reform to battle Italy over budget (Image: )EU officials believe the &euro2.3 trillion debt could act as a &ldquocontagion across weaker Eurozone countries and could spark a new financial crisis.Allowing tempers to flare between Brussels and Rome will only act in further stalling the efforts to reform the Eurozone to protect itself against potential meltdown.Under Italy&rsquos plans to spend more borrowed money than allowed under EU rules, dreams of a Eurozone budget and deposit scheme towards future bailouts are moving further out of reach.One official said: &ldquoIt is going to be more difficult now.&ldquoWhen you talk about deposit insurance, the appetite is smaller.&ldquoItaly is an additional argument not to even think about it.Others believe Rome&rsquos actions are also harming confidence in the Eurozone&rsquos southern and more fragile states &ndash Spain, Portugal and Greece.Some suggest calls for a German championed mechanism that would see a country&rsquos market access cut to ensure they comply with fiscal rules could return as a result.&ldquoMy fear is that because of the situation in Italy, Germany can say that market discipline is a good thing because the Commission cannot enforce the rules, a second official said.&ldquoMaybe this can also start to convince France, if we have countries that deliberately break the rules and don&rsquot really care about the Stability and Growth Pact any more.Mr Verhofstadt told EU leaders in Strasbourg they risk sleepwalking into the next financial crash if they allow a row with Italy to stand in the way of reforms.He said: &ldquoIt has now been ten years since the outbreak of the financial crisis and no new governance systems for the Eurozone have been put in place.&ldquoWake up Mr Tusk, the next financial crisis is knocking on our door.Matteo Salvini and the EU have clashed since he came to power as part of a populist coalition (Image: )He added: &ldquoMr Tusk, the way you and your colleagues in the Council evade their responsibility is a dereliction of duty sleep walking to a new financial catastrophe.&ldquoWhen are you going to change your methods?&ldquoWhen are you going to lock your colleagues into a meeting room &ndash no new clothes, no new underwear &ndash until they have taken their responsibility, until they have reformed our migration policies?The warnings are there, Brussels must now tread carefully to ensure a potential conflict with Rome does not consign the Eurozone to a slow death thanks to ignoring the need for reform.

story: Speaking to France24, the Five Star Movement MEP argued Italy's internal surplus proved to be better than Germany's, claiming Italy is in a strong position to be defiant on its budget proposals.Ms Beghin also claimed Italy benefits from the solidarity of other member states who agree the European Commission should not be dictating the way forward.She said: I think that we will maintain our position, we are strong enough to maintain our position because we are Italy.&ldquoWe are the third contributors of the EU budget, and we have solidarity from other countries that have stated in the last hour that it is impossible for the EU Commission to have such a position towards a member state.                How EU row with Italy can CONDEMN the Eurozone to history                Economist warns Italy of crisis risks during budget clash with EU&ldquoThis is a political signal. This is not an evaluation made with a correct analysis.&ldquoIt&rsquos just an opinion. We are not violating at all. We have an internal balance that is positive since almost 27 years.&ldquoWe are better than other countries like Germany for example.&ldquoOur internal surplus is nearly 13 percent, that is just five percent in Germany.EU news: Italian MEP claims Italy is in a better position than Germany (Image: LA7&bull)&ldquoSo we did all the best that we could to make spending reviews, to cut, to make reforms, but it didn&rsquot help to increase our GDP.&ldquoI didn&rsquot help to change our economic situation.&ldquoNow we need to invest, not to spend money, we need to invest in a pragmatic way.Tensions between Rome and Brussels continue to rise following the European Commission's rejection of Italy's budget proposals.&nbspThe EU institution has given the Italian eurosceptic Government three weeks to come back with a reviewed plan.But Deputy Prime Ministers Matteo Salvini and Luigi Di Maio remain defiant against Brussels decision and have announced to stick to the proposal.&nbspLuigi Di Maio,&nbspsaid the government will not adjust its 2019 budget deficit target and insists it does not want to leave the bloc or the single currency, despite the European Commission demanding changes.The Five Star Movement leader said his government is not &ldquorespecting the EU&rsquos rules and reiterated the Italian&rsquos desire to stay in the eurozone.He said: &ldquoMarkets are not concerned about Italy not respecting the EU budget rules.&ldquoInvestors are worried about false storytelling according to which Italy wants to leave the euro and the European Union. That is not that case.

title: Greece earthquake zante USGS magnitude 6 8 today news
story: The epicentre of the 6.8 magnitude quake was located in the Ionian Sea, near the Greek Island of Zante and about 50 miles north-east of the city of Pyrgos.The quake had a depth of around 16 kilometres.So far, three people have been taken to hospital.&nbspThe series of earthquakes have continued into Friday early afternoon around the islands of Lithakia and Mouzaki.                Natural global warming led to TWO mass extinctions                Earthquake WARNING: Earth enters &lsquoCRITICAL&rsquo period for major tremorThe quakes to rock the area following the big 6.8 one had lower magnitudes of between 4.5 and 5.2.One British tourist Joanna Jones described the 6.8 magnitude earthquake experience as being in Jumanji.She said: &ldquoHave you seen the new Jumanji? That was exactly what it was like. The floor, beds and every bit of furniture bouncing and shaking up and down.Thirty minutes before the powerful earthquake struck, a quake with a magnitude of five stuck close to Lithakia.Some damage reported on Zakynthos, Greece from last night's magnitude 6.8 earthquake (Image: EMSC*@severeweatherEU)Civil protection agency press spokesman Spyros Gorgiou said: &ldquoWe&rsquore checking out the villages on the islands, where there are several older buildings.&ldquoThe lack of electricity is a problem, but technicians are trying to restore power.&nbspA witness said online: Me and my partner are staying in Zante, it woke my partner up, and we've had three aftershocks much smaller, the larger quake has moved several items around the room.Another witness described the tremors to the European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre (EMSC) saying there was extremely violent shaking.He added: Objects fell off shelves.Loud rumbling.The impacts of the earthquake in Greece  (Image: @severeweatherEU)Damages are seen at the port of the island of Zakynthos, Ionian Sea, west Greece (Image: EPA)According to reports, the quake lasted 15 to 30 seconds.The EMSC said the earthquake sparked a small tsunami of 15 to 20 cm on local beaches.&nbspLocal media reported that a 15th century monastery in the Strofades area of the island has been damaged.The USGS shows where the quake struck  (Image: EPA)                Taiwan earthquake: 5.7 quake SHAKES Taipei - Ring of Fire on alertItaly's Il Messaggero news site reported that the earthquake was felt as far as southern Italy.It claimed firefighters in the regions of Sicily, Calabria and Puglia received thousands of phone calls after the quake struck.According to the USGS, a local small tsunami is possible and residents have been advised to move away from the shores.A 6.8 earthquake is listed by the USGS as very strong with the potential for &ldquomoderate damage.The quake was felt as far as South Italy, Albania and Macedonia (Image: EMSC)The scientific agency claimed as many as 19.3 million people could have felt the earthquake, including 54,000 people who may have experienced strong to very strong shaking.The USGS said: Overall, the population in this region resides in structures that are a mix of vulnerable and earthquake resistant construction.Some damage is possible and the impact should be relatively localised.Greece lies in one of the world's most earthquake-prone regions, and thousands of quakes are recorded every year.Additional reporting by Martina Bet&nbsp

title: us bomb new york florida corey booker democrat senator manhattan post office
story: A bomb threat was earlier sparked in Florida after a suspicious package was sent to Democrat Senator Corey Booker&rsquos office, while police rush to a New York postal facility with another suspect package.The FBI confirmed they have recovered the suspicious package addressed to US Senator Booker.Mr Booker is a prominent critic of US President Donald Trump.The latest package was found at a mail sorting facility in Florida and was addressed to the Democratic senator from New Jersey, the FBI said on Twitter.New York City police were investigating a suspicious package at a postal facility on Friday morning as well, authorities said.                New York pipe bomb sent to CNN had ISIS parody flagDog units and a police bomb squad rushed to the scene at the US mail distribution centre in Opa-Locka, north-west Miami.It is the eleventh suspicious package sent to Donald Trump critics this week.US Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen said that Florida appeared to be the starting point for at least some of the bomb shipments.She told Fox News Channel yesterday: Some of the packages went through the mail. They originated, some of them, from Florida.New York police have swarmed a post office after a suspicious package was intercepted (Image: SKY)I am confident that this person or people will be brought to justice.Authorities have called the parcel bombs acts of terrorism.They have been sent less than two weeks before crucial midterm elections, taking place on November 6.All those targeted have been lambasted by right-wing critics.Among them are former Secretary of State and presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, former President Barack Obama, former Vice President Joe Biden, and Democratic Party donor George Soros.At least five packages had a return address from the Florida office of US Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, a former chair of the Democratic National Committee, the FBI said.No one has claimed responsibility for the bombs, and the public was asked to report any tips.Authorities believe the packages, which were intercepted before reaching their intended recipients, all went through the US Postal Service at some point, a source said. None detonated and no one has been hurt.The devices were thought to have been fashioned from bomb-making designs widely available on the internet, a federal law enforcement source told Reuters.Still, investigators are treating the devices as live explosives, not a hoax, said James O'Neill, the New York City police commissioner. Two of the parcels surfaced there.William Sweeney, assistant director of the FBI, told a news conference in New York: It does remain possible that further packages have been or could be mailedInvestigators have declined to say whether the devices were built to be functional. Bomb experts and security analysts say that based on their rudimentary construction it appeared they were more likely designed to sow fear rather than to kill.The parcels each consisted of a manila envelope with a bubble-wrap interior containing potentially destructive devices, the FBI said. Each was affixed with a computer-printed address label and six U.S. Forever postage stamps, the agency said.Others who received the bombs were former Attorney General Eric Holder, former CIA director John Brennan, U.S. Representative Maxine Waters of California, and actor Robert De Nero. Two packages were sent both to Waters and Biden.Brennan's package was sent in care of the New York bureau of CNN, where he has appeared as an on-air analyst.The episode sparked an outcry from Trump's critics, who charged that his inflammatory rhetoric against Democrats and the press has created a climate for politically motivated violence.After first calling for unity and civil discourse on Wednesday, Trump lashed out again Thursday at the hateful media. His supporters accused Democrats of unfairly suggesting the president was to blame for the bomb scare.Mr Trump wrote on Twitter in the early hours of this morning: Funny how lowly rated CNN, and others, can criticise me at will, even blaming me for the current spate of Bombs and ridiculously comparing this to September 11th and the Oklahoma City bombing, yet when I criticise them they go wild and scream, &lsquoit's just not Presidential!&rsquoTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS STORY. MORE TO FOLLOW.

story: Lewis Hamilton has backed the young Schumacher  (Image: )Schumacher Junior, 19, who is the son of the seven-time Formula 1 champion Michael, took a 347-point lead at the weekend in the European F3 series.Lewis Hamilton said to formula1: &ldquoSo there will 100 percent be a Schumacher back in Formula 1, partly because of the name, but secondly because he's doing a great job.&ldquoHe's obviously got a lot of talent as his Dad had, just like Keke and Nico Rosberg, just like when Fernando has kids I'm sure an Alonso will be here again.Mick was only 14 when he was with his father in the French Alps in 2013 when the F1 legend suffered life-changing head injuries following a ski accident. title: what red budget box philip hammond gladstone despatch
story: The red box is used to transport the Budget speech and dates back to former PM and four-time Chancellor William Gladstone in the th century.The red box, which carries the Budget speech from No. to the House of Commons, is often held up outside  Downing Street by the Chancellor.According to HM Treasury: Ministers are permitted to use ordinary lockable briefcases to transport information which has been classied ‘Confidential’ or below.For information with a higher security levelthey are required to use despatch boxes, which offer a higher level of security, and which are usually red. The briefcase has been used for more than  years with the first box being made for William Gladstone in .Gladstones box was lined with black satin and covered with scarlet leather.Gladstones original red Budget box was used by every UK Chancellor until  with the exception of James Callaghanand Gordon Brownwho both had new cases commissioned.It has been suggested that Callaghan said Gladstones was too small and had a bigger one made from brown leather.Gladstones original box was brought out of retirement in  when is was used by Alistair Darling until .George Osborne also used it in June .It has now been officially retired for good due to its fragility and is due to be displayed in the Cabinet War Rooms in London.Since March , a new box commissioned by The National Archives has been used.The box is used to deliver the new UK Budget which tells us Brits how the government will be spending money.It usually contains the Chancellors Budget speech which is why it is seen as important.But there have been a few mishaps over the years.In , Chancellor George Ward-Hunt reportedly suffered an embarrassing moment when he turned up at Parliament and opened the briefcase, only to discover he had left his speech at home.The mishap is believed to have inspired the tradition in which the Chancellor holds up the box to the crowd when he leaves No..Norman Lamont, who was chancellor from -, allegedly carried a bottle of whisky in his briefcase while his speech was carried in a plastic bag by his then-aide William Hague.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: make this budget philips last
story: Next Monday, on the eve of Halloween, Phil Hammond will raise the curtain on his latest tax-hiking non-Tory Budget.If there’s any justice, it will be his last.If Theresa May’s Downing Street days are numbered, so should those be of her Death Watch Chancellor.Together, they are the unrivalled stars of Tory MP Johnny Mercer’s glorious Whitehall farce, “The Sh*t Show”.Excitable critics say Mrs May is entering a “killing zone”.Rivals jockey for position while party chiefs try to streamline the timetable for picking her successor.This Prime Minister’s Number Ten tenancy is almost up. So is Hammond’s next door.Whoever takes over — Boris, David Davis or Jeremy Hunt — needs an emergency clear-out.The big guns of the Treasury need to be pointed at the “enemy” not its own side.After two long, wasted years, Britain is engaged in an unexpectedly desperate fight, not just to salvage Brexit but to save British democracy.Weekend crowds demanding a second referendum seem oblivious to the threat such a crazy re-run would pose to this nation’s centuries-old stability, ironically the envy of Europe.We cannot reverse the  referendum without turning Brexit into a perpetual running sore. And Britain can never rejoin the EU except on its knees.The only way to put this corrosive issue to bed is for Brexit to succeed — as it will, despite treacherous Tony Blair and Facebook hypocrite Nick Clegg.To succeed as we must we need a new chancellor as well as a new prime minister.Diehard Remainer Phil Hammond should be first out the door.It was Spreadsheet Phil who vetoed vital preparations for No Deal — now a better-than - prospect with time rapidly running out.And it was Hammond who surrendered the one negotiating weapon Brussels fears most — a thriving, low-tax Britain competing with the EU on its doorstep.Our economic fate is entirely in our hands. We can make taxes and tarfs as competitive as we like.Better investment incentives and lower corporation tax rates would trigger a flood of foreign investment in UK plc — and ensure car makers like Nissan and Toyota never leave our shores.Yet the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has ruled them out.“Phil is like those Harry Potter Dementor creatures,” says a top Tory. “He sucks the le out of any room he happens to be in.”Hammond is easily replaced. Michael Gove, an ex-future PM but a formidable Cabinet minister, has the drive and imagination to take on the Treasury “Blob”.There is no shortage of Brexit talent on the Tory benches.Just compare thundering Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC with prissy dried-stick predecessor Dominic Grieve.Grieve is busy sabotaging Brexit. Cox finds ways to make it work.He is now “marking Number Ten’s homework” on Mrs May’s wretched Northern Ireland “backstop”.Some even tip him as a dark horse in the leadership stakes.There is one other big change needed at the heart of Britain’s Brexit team.Our next PM must have a new EU negotiator.Nobody could be worse than Olly Robbins, already reportedly eyeing up a £m-a-year golden parachute into a top City job.Lelong Europhile Robbins has led Mrs May into so many disastrous EU traps — especially her humiliation in Salzburg — he is often cast as an EU “double agent”.It was Robbins who told EU negotiator Michel Barnier that Britain might stay indefinitely in “transition” while the fantasy Northern Ireland backstop was sorted out.And pay £bn more on top of the £bn ransom for the privilege.The idea that Robbins is the “EU’s man in Whitehall” is not such a stretch when you consider his Jeremy Corbyn-style applause for Communist Russia.Kremlin leaders, he told fellow Oxford students in , “changed Russia from a backward peasant autocracy, despised by the West, into a technological giant at whom the world cowered in fear for half a century.”Everyone is entitled to youthful naivety.But can anyone imagine Olly Robbins fighting our corner for EU democracy and accountability, let alone the referendum verdict of .m Brexit-voting Brits SAUDI Arabia’s rulers must be really annoyed with dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.This elderly trouble maker walked alone into his country’s Turkish consulate knowing he might never emerge alive.He was clearly looking for trouble.Once inside, using his bare hands, he attacked a gang of  innocent Saudi torturers who had just flown in for a couple of hours’ holiday armed only with a bone saw and a hypodermic syringe.Then, to the embarrassment of kindly Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, he went and hid his own body.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. There’ll be nothing funny for the Irish economyyour cack-handed comedy routine stops you trading with your closest neighbour.It’s getting serious. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. The medieval process to deal with complaints simply cannot stand.The hypocrisy of MPs, who interfere in workplaces across the country on a daily basis, is staggering.The insufferable Speaker John Bercow has shown no appetite to give Commons staff the rights they deserve.Parliament must act.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. That means being a part of a global economy. One in which the Japanese can build cars in the North East, American outfits can trade in the City and, yes, navy blue British passports can be made in France.Protectionism is a race to the bottom.BRITAIN now has the fourth lowest rate of home ownership in the EU.It is a damning indictment of decades of failed housing policy. Next week’s Budget is a chance for a radical sea change to ensure our property-owning democracy survives for generations.Don’t blow it, Chancellor.MPs shouldn’t have to march on Downing Street to end the witch-hunt against Northern Ireland veterans.But the PM and Cabinet must listen.The disgraceful pursuit must stop.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mo bros set to cycle 6000 miles from london to tokyo to help prevent men dying young and it all started over a pint
story: But for most of us, as sobriety creeps back in, the time comes to dismiss our drunken ramblings as nothing more.Not the case for two mates from Hertfordshire, as a booze-filled decision to cycle around the world kick-started what promises to be the biggest challenge of their lives so far - and one which could save the lives of young men just like themselves.George Cullen, , and Ben Cook, , will embark on a ,-mile bicycle journey from London to Tokyo in March next year, all in the name of mens health.Known as The Hairy Handlebars, the pair will tackle the enormous trip with nothing more than their bikes, tents, some lycra and a whole lot of grit in the hope of raising £, for The Movember Foundation.Passing through  countries in total, their route takes them from Covent Garden through mainland Europe, following the Danube River to Istanbul, then on to Aktau in Central Asia.They will then continue through the Kazakhstan desert and across the famous Pamir Highway, before travelling around , miles through China and over to Osaka to reach their final destination in the Japanese capital.Having spent the early stages of their careers as a professional rugby player and a Royal Marine, respectively, both George and Ben are used to high-pressure situations.Even so, their cycle will pose a number of new challenges and dangers, as it sees them battle harsh weather, terrain, wildle and even potential terrorist activity during their six-month haul.Since setting their minds on the task more than year ago, the duo have linked up with the global mens health charity to become the faces of this years Movember campaign.But while they are passionate about raising funds for such a worthy cause, the journey itself came about due to a longing for something more.The desire to escape the monotony of everyday le and see the world in a unique way was initially the key motivator for their trip.As the idea evolved, it then became obvious that an adventure of this scale was the perfect opportunity to get people talking about the key health issues facing men just like themselves.Explaining their motives in their first blog, The Hairy Handlebars said: We see that mental health is an issue that is spiralling out of control in young men.Suicide in young males is a brutally high killer as men are forced into adhering to certain social norms that simply don’t reflect their true self.Now, of course, our adventure could be seen as the very embodiment of a testosterone-fuelled escapade.However, we are undertaking this for what can be construed as far more romantic reasons a desire to actually escape these norms that are creating the problem in the first place, coupled with a desire to see the world in the rawest way possible.As well as raising as much money as possible, perhaps we can provide inspiration to men to not adhere to the boundaries that have been set for them and steer them away from subsequent mental health issues.With plans to finish their trip in time for the  Rugby World Cup in Japan, the pair have also developed strong links with members of the rugby community.England captain Dylan Hartley is a keen supporter of the cause, and they have also joined up with Premiership side Harlequins charity foundation.And the pairs rugby club, National One side Bishops Stortford, will hold a Movember Round in support of their cause.Part of their fundraising effort will also go towards setting up a foundation in memory of Ian Williams, a former professional rugby player who passed away suddenly in February.The foundation will focus on mental health and cardiac issues in young athletes.George Cullen said: A huge motivation for us is the chance to raise awareness of mental health issues in men.As things stand, the ability for men to get things off their chest, a proven relief of mental health problems, is simply not where it needs to be.We have to get to a point where men are able to talk openly about their issues and seek help, whether from mates, family or a professional.We both recognise the fact that we have had our own issues, and as a result know the value of having people around you who will listen.We hope that we can do our own small bit in ensuring no man has to suffer in silence -that means getting one man to reach out to someone about their problems, then taking on our cycle will be worth it.The Hairy Handlebars hope to raise £, for The Movember Foundation. title: freedom of the press sun says gagging claims
story: Yesterday, it was revealed that the Dailyhas been stopped from revealing the name of a prominent businessman who — on at least five occasions — has used non-disclosure agreements and hush money to silence allegations against him.Is it in the public interest for a loaded businessman to be able to silence the Press by spending half a million quid on legal proceedings Or for the public to know what he’s been accused of, and paid handsome sums to keep it quiet Ask yourself this:a member of your family was applying for a job working for him, wouldn’t you want to know The #MeToo scandal showed just how far powerful figures will go to keep their victims schtum. title: mexico pyramid of the moon hidden tunnels
story: Researchers have revealed they discovered a new tunnel and a cavity hidden below an archaeological site near Mexico City.Details of the stunning discoveries were given in a statement from the investigators of the National Institute of Anthropology and History.Veronica Ortega, the director of the Project of Integral Conservation of Plaza de la Luna, which is the central square in the complex, said the investigation is focused on a ritual space linked to the underworld.Mrs Ortega said the investigation into the cavity, which is believed to have been used as a chamber, will allow them to determine the connections that this old metropolis had with other regions of Mesoameric.The discovery of the chamber and tunnel is a result of a initial study using electrical resistivity carried out around the Pyramid of the Moon in June .Electric resistivity methods are a form of geophysical surveying which help create an image of the subsurface. These methods utilise dferences in electric potential to identy subsurface material. The cavity, which experts believe could have been dedicated to rituals, is  feet below the pyramid and is  feet in diameter.The tunnel is located towards the south of the Plaza de la Luna and experts believe there could be another entry to the east.The Pyramid of the Moon is the second largest pyramid in Mexico after the Pyramid of the Sun. Its structure existed prior to  AD.Studies from  gave an indication of the possible existence of a chamber and the archaeologists have now confirmed the existence of the chamber.The city of Teotihuacan is believed to have been established around  BCE.It is believed to have been built by the Toltec before the Aztecs arrived.In research carried out in the late s at the site archaeologists Ruben Cabrera and Saburo Sugiyama discovered skeletons with cranial deformations along with objects from green stone.

story: Some cash in by mentioning the Royal British Legion, whose Poppy Appeal began yesterday, despite having no official links.One, Scarlett Jewellery, called its baubles — including a £ gold charm — a “symbol of remembrance, a symbol of the Royal British Legion to never forget those we lost”.And Shrieking Violet says its items, one a teardrop charm, are “perfect for remembrance”.Another firm, Poppyshopliveon.org.uk, even uses a web address similar to the Legion’s Poppyshop.org.uk.Its pages feature forces pictures and the slogan “Lest we forget”.It claims proceeds from its gems “benefit the British Legion”.But customers who asked were just told it gave “ten to  per cent” to good causes, with no confirmation any went to the Legion.Elizabeth Minder, , a Legion fundraiser and poppy seller in Redhill, Surrey, said: “It makes my blood boil.“Profiteering from such an honourable cause is saddening. It’s stooping low to earn from the dead.”TV channel QVC, an official ­Legion partner, was also rapped for giving just a third of proceeds and hiding that in small print.Items include £ brooches with the dates  and  to mark the Armistice Day centenary.Its website urges buyers to “wear the poppy and support The Royal British Legion and Poppyscotland”.Legion supporter Ron Grenald, , of Hants, rapped: “You would never know they gave that small an amount unless you looked for it.It’s disgraceful. Big stores should donate all the profits, like Marks  Spencer does.”Intellectual property minister Sam Gyimah said: “It’s shocking anyone would exploit one of our most cherished charities and take advantage of support for our Armed Forces.”Theresa May helped launch this year’s appeal as she met war veteran Barbara Weatherill, , and poppy seller Poppy Railton, nine, at No.Artworks were unveiled UK-wide, one a ft-high poppy installation at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, South East London.Last night Brighton-based Scarlett, which also sells a £ enamel charm and a £ silver one, said: “We used to give  per cent of the enamel sales to the Legion. title: us mail bombs who has been sent the suspect packages and what do we know about the devices
